title: Section C
passagesOne: Questions 46 to 50 are based on the following passage.

questionsOne.Statement: When are people likely to experience boredom, according to an accepted psychological definition?

Options.text: When they don't have the chance to do what they want.
When they don't enjoy the materials they are studying.
When they experience something unpleasant.
When they engage in some routine activities.

questionsOne.Statement: What does the author say boredom can lead to?

Options.text: Determination.
Concentration
Mental deterioration.
Harmful conduct.

questionsOne.Statement: What is the finding of one team of psychologists in their experiment?

Options.text: Volunteers prefer watching a boring movie to sitting alone deliberating.
Many volunteers choose to hurt themselves rather than endure boredom.
Male volunteers are more immune to the effects of boredom than females.
Many volunteers are unable to resist boredom longer than fifteen minutes.

questionsOne.Statement: Why does the author say boredom isn't all bad?

Options.text: It stimulates memorization.
It allows time for relaxation.
It may promote creative thinking.
It may facilitate independent learning.

questionsOne.Statement: What does the author suggest one do when faced with a challenging problem?

Options.text: Stop idling and think big.
Unlock one's smartphone.
Look around oneself for stimulation.
Allow oneself some time to be bored.

passagesTwo: Questions 51 to 55 are based on the following passage.

questionsTwo.Statement: What is catching environmentalists' attention nowadays?

Options.text: Rich countries are stripping poor ones of their resources.
Forests are fast shrinking in many developing countries.
Forests are eating away the fertile farmland worldwide.
Rich countries are doing little to address deforestation.

questionsTwo.Statement: Which countries have the fastest forest growth?

Options.text: Those that have newly achieved independence.
Those that have the greatest demand for timber.
Those that used to have the lowest forest coverage.
Those that provide enormous government subsidies.

questionsTwo.Statement: What has encouraged forest growth historically?

Options.text: The government's advocacy.
The use of wood for fuel.
The favourable climate.
The green movement.

questionsTwo.Statement: What accounts for our increasing desire for forests?

Options.text: Their unique scenic beauty.
Their use as fruit plantations.
Their capability of improving air quality.
Their stable supply of building materials.

questionsTwo.Statement: What does the author conclude about the prospects of forestation?

Options.text: Deserts in sub-Saharan Africa will diminish gradually.
It will play a more and more important role in people's lives.
Forest destruction in the developing world will quickly slow down.
Developed and developing countries are moving in opposite directions.
